column1: {"body": "Shortly after Mayor Bill de Blasio and his national advocacy group trumpeted plans last month to hold a presidential forum in Iowa
column2: the mayor hopped on a conference call to rev up the liberal faithful.\n\nAddressing members from around the country
column3: the mayor spoke of girding for a sustained war on inequality \u2014 the very topic of the Dec. 6 forum
column4: which organizers believed would be a harbinger of the group\u2019s intent to play on the national stage.\n\nThose plans collapsed this week. The de Blasio-backed group canceled its event
column5: explaining in a statement that it would redirect its energies into other methods of tackling inequality.\n\nOn Wednesday
column6: Mr. de Blasio acknowledged a more humbling reality: Not a single presidential candidate had agreed to attend.\n\nThe disintegration of the Iowa conclave was the most significant setback yet for the Progressive Agenda Committee
column7: an ambitious but halting enterprise that has prompted questions about Mr. de Blasio\u2019s political judgment
column8: and has tested his clout as a local official with baldly ideological aspirations.\n\nMr. de Blasio and his allies say the group is a necessary vehicle to rally liberal elites behind a cohesive message. Inspired by a policy agenda that Mr. de Blasio unveiled in Washington in May
column9: covering topics from union rights to international trade
column10: the Progressive Agenda Committee is now incorporated as a nonprofit
column11: with its own executive director and political director.\n\nBut the project
column12: founded by Mr. de Blasio and backed by influential labor leaders and former City Hall aides
column13: has faced a series of unexpected setbacks: Prominent elected officials have hesitated to commit themselves. Some leaders who endorsed Mr. de Blasio\u2019s policy manifesto have had second thoughts about promoting such a grandly ideological document.\n\nEven the rise of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont in the presidential race has presented a challenge for the Progressive Agenda
column14: forcing the group to reconsider its goals now that a self-described socialist has already electrified the Democratic primary with heated rhetoric about inequality. (Mr. de Blasio endorsed Hillary Rodham Clinton last month.)\n\nThe project has also sharply divided advisers to Mr. de Blasio
column15: some of whom counseled the mayor to reconsider the Iowa forum
column16: concerned that it had deepened perceptions of Mr. de Blasio as excessively preoccupied with national politics
column17: according to people familiar with their reservations.\n\nThese people
column18: who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss private conversations
column19: said Mr. de Blasio held out on having the forum until just days before the plug was pulled
column20: convinced that the event would ultimately advance the broader cause of his liberal group.\n\nOthers in the mayor\u2019s circle remain intensely committed: John Del Cecato
column21: one of Mr. de Blasio\u2019s closest advisers who is widely viewed as the most enthusiastic champion of the project
column22: defended it this week as having helped move the national political debate in a liberal direction.\n\nMr. de Blasio stressed Wednesday that he was invested in making the Progressive Agenda a success
column23: and vowed to put \u201cyears and years of effort\u201d into pressing its inequality message forward.\n\n\u201cWe are going to be doing activities all over the country and in Washington to keep pushing the issue of income inequality to the fore
column26: \u201cWe\u2019re going to keep trying new strategies until we find the ones that we think work best.\u201d\n\nAmid the public clamor over Mr. de Blasio\u2019s foray into presidential politics
column27: other aspects of the Progressive Agenda Committee have begun to take shape.\n\nThe organization
column28: which at first appeared aimed at shaping the 2016 election by pressuring Mrs. Clinton from the left
column29: has sketched out a more gradual timeline for its activities
column30: aimed at preparing to extract liberal policy achievements from the next president.\n\nGeri Prado
column31: a former A.F.L.-C.I.O. strategist who joined the Progressive Agenda Committee over the summer as its executive director
column32: said the group had begun to assemble a \u201cmessage calendar\u201d for the progressive movement aimed squarely at the first quarter of 2017.\n\n\u201cWe want to make sure that in the first 100 days of 2017
column33: people are fulfilling their promises around income inequality
column34: \u201d Ms. Prado said in an interview.\n\nMs. Prado
column36: has wooed liberal leaders with a PowerPoint presentation that ticks off a series of national ills \u2014 including the \u201cCorporatization of America\u201d \u2014 and detailed tactics to address them.\n\nThe function of the committee
column37: according to a copy of the presentation
column38: is to help provide message discipline for a diverse array of activist communities on the left.\n\nThe presentation repeatedly invokes the image of a religious congregation
column39: and states that this particular group\u2019s role is to provide \u201chymnals for the choir.\u201d\n\nThe Progressive Agenda intends to hold regular planning calls featuring a range of liberal leaders \u2014 not just Mr. de Blasio \u2014 outlining the elements of what it views as a successful progressive economic message
column40: according to people familiar with the plans. (It has already held calls to highlight research by the Roosevelt Institute
column43: a Democratic polling project focused on economic messaging.)\n\nIn mass emails
column44: organizers have urged members of the group to help create a drumbeat around key liberal priorities: One message last Friday offered up sample Twitter posts
column45: suggesting that members use social media to proclaim
column46: \u201cWall Street and the superrich are gaming the stock market.\u201d\n\nThe group has also taken steps to reduce Mr. de Blasio\u2019s presence: The mayor\u2019s name did not appear on the invitations sent to presidential candidates
column47: and organizers said that he would have played no speaking role at the forum.\n\nStill
column48: Mr. de Blasio confers with Ms. Prado at least once a week about the group\u2019s activities. And if the group is aiming to channel a broader set of voices
column50: Mr. de Blasio and the stature of his office have plainly been the animating forces behind its public activities so far.\n\nThe first glimmers of the Progressive Agenda emerged last spring
column51: when Mr. de Blasio convened an April meeting at Gracie Mansion with other left-leaning Democrats
column52: to discuss economic issues. By the next month
column53: at least two City Hall aides
column55: were involved in efforts to recruit endorsers for the Progressive Agenda
column56: according to emails obtained through public records requests.\n\nEarly on
column57: Mr. de Blasio personally solicited support for the agenda from leading Democrats. Howard Dean
column58: the former Vermont governor and presidential candidate
column59: said he joined the group because of a direct appeal from Mr. de Blasio
column60: and called it a useful gathering point for liberal leaders.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s basically trying to
column62: put together a counterweight to the right
column65: \u201cThere are not that many forums where national progressives all get together and talk.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. de Blasio\u2019s back-channel recruitment efforts also revealed his limitations as a liberal field marshal. He repeatedly sought support from Edwin M. Lee
column66: the mayor of San Francisco and a fellow Democrat
column67: telling him in a personal email that his backing would be a \u201cgreat boost\u201d to the Progressive Agenda.\n\nWhen Mr. Lee offered a noncommittal response
column68: Mr. de Blasio pressed the issue
column69: asking him to consider signing on by the following day. Mr. Lee did not.\n\nOther outreach efforts have yielded only impermanent results. Mr. Sanders
column70: whom the mayor has praised as an important spokesman for the left
column71: agreed in a phone call with Mr. de Blasio to participate in the Iowa forum. But the Sanders campaign never ultimately made a formal commitment.\n\nEven among officials who signed on to the group
column72: some have balked at promoting the Progressive Agenda with their own energies.\n\nMayor Steve Adler of Austin
column74: gave his stamp of approval to Mr. de Blasio\u2019s policy manifesto
column75: but in emails privately fretted with aides about how far to take the partnership. \u201cMuch of this is national stuff
column81: said there were areas of overlap between the Texas mayor\u2019s ideas and Mr. de Blasio\u2019s liberal platform. But
column83: \u201cThere are other things there that just aren\u2019t part of our agenda that are perceived as national political issues
column84: and not what the mayor\u2019s trying to accomplish here in Austin.\u201d"

column8:
but his platform of mixing Fernandez's

column3: Fathers and the Changing American Family\" and \"Raising Boys Without Men.\" She is an assistant professor of psychology at Weill Cornell Medical College of Cornell University and a former gender scholar at Stanford University. Join her on Facebook and follow her on Twitter @drpeggydrexler. The opinions expressed in this commentary are solely those of the author. \n (CNN)This week
column4: the election season took a turn for the predictable as Hillary Clinton's hair became the topic of conversation in a Donald Trump media appearance. \nTrump was chatting with Mark Levin
column5: a conservative talk radio host who wanted to know what Trump suspected voters liked most about Clinton. Trump's response was characteristically provocative
column6: if entirely off-point: \"Well
column8: \" Trump replied. \"Did you notice that today?\"\nThat wasn't all. He then went on to call Clinton's hair \"shocking
column9: \" \"massive\" and agreeing with Levin's suggestion that the pile of hair atop his opponent's head \"must be\" a wig. \nPolitics as usual
column10: right? \nWhat a woman looks like -- her weight
column12: how much makeup she does or doesn't wear --has remained stubbornly front and center in the world of working women
column15: public office. Despite being one of history's most successful female political figures
column16: Clinton has been judged for decades on how she looks: for those pantsuits
column17: for her choice of hair accessories
column18: for her weight
column19: you name it. \nThroughout
column20: many have argued that such comments are directed at Clinton
column22: simply because they're women; that no male candidate would be subjected to such constant analysis of hair
column26: in the wake of Trump's comments last night
column27: it would be easy to say that things haven't really changed; that even when talking about one of the world's most powerful women
column28: matters still come down to how good we think she looks.  \nExcept it's not entirely true that women are on the receiving end of all the focus on appearance.\nHillary Clinton
column30: made fun of Trump's hair in a bit on Jimmy Fallon (\"just one strand that he twirls over his head like a soft serve at Dairy Queen\")  And let's not forget all the girl talk about Mitt Romney's good looks or judgment of his expensive haircut as a signal of \"wealthy privilege.\" Meanwhile
column31: President Barack Obama's personal style continues to garner praise -- that is
column32: when he's not taking heat over his \"mom jeans.\" \nDonald Trump
column34: has no filter. He says what he thinks
column35: seemingly as soon as he thinks it
column36: and it's not always appetizing. That's why people love him
column37: and also why people don't. It's certainly why he's still generating headline news.  \nAnd yet
column38: in his conversation with the Levin -- which
column39: given that Levin is a well-known conservative
column40: had an agenda from the get-go -- Trump doesn't actually say anything negative or positive about Clinton's hair. He brings it up out of context
column41: sure. But he never actually says it doesn't look good. \nBut so what if he did? The truth is that appearance is part of life
column42: and a pretty big one. \nIn politics
column43: it may not be something to celebrate
column44: necessarily -- certainly not a legitimate reason to elect or not elect someone to office -- but it needn't be something to entirely ignore
column45: either. That's just not how the rest of the world works; why should politics be any different? \nMore importantly
column46: the way to end sexism isn't to stop acknowledging a woman's appearance altogether. That's not evolution; that's just forced silence
column47: which is quite possibly as damning
column49: as making appearance the only thing that matters. \nIn fact
column50: let's consider that the greatest amount of attention put on Clinton's new hairstyle wasn't Trump's doing; it was the doing of everyone else who took his comments and ran with them
column51: turning a blowhard's observation into something resembling an attack. \nClinton may very well be wearing a wig. It seems unlikely
column52: but who cares? Many women do. So do many men.\nDoes Trump? Well
column53: the world continues to marvel at his odd locks. Perhaps enduring many years of public taunting about them has encouraged him to do the same to others or at least sent him the message that the topic isn't off-limits. That

column56: if anyone's going to do the bullying
column57: it's Trump. Not the rest of us. \nJoin us on Facebook.com/CNNOpinion.Read CNNOpinion's Flipboard magazine. \n"

column2: Hillary Rodham Clinton appears vastly better positioned than Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont to persuade party primary voters that she would be more effective at passing her agenda and dealing with international crises

column9:

column1: {"body": " (AP) \u00e2\u0080\u0094 For months
column2: Marco Rubio's campaign team in South Carolina operated out of a staffer's garage
column3: plotting strategy for the first-in-the-South primary from freshly painted yard sale furniture and tiny classroom desks.\nThe shoestring budget setup was a point of pride for the Republican presidential candidate's team. Now
column4: with Rubio enjoying a burst of momentum as the early voting contests edge closer
column5: the Florida senator's campaign is moving beyond its lean and mean roots.\nOn Wednesday
column6: Rubio's South Carolina team officially moved out of the garage and into a proper campaign headquarters \u00e2\u0080\u0094 though they brought some of the yard sale furniture along with them.\n\"This election could very well be decided in this state
column7: \" Rubio told the crowd gathered at the office in Columbia
column8: South Carolina's capital.\nRubio's team also opened offices in Nevada a few weeks ago. His staff grew by about 30 percent in October
column9: with more than 70 people now on the campaign payroll. The new hires include communications and digital advisers
column10: as well as field workers to boost voter contact and advance staff to help set up larger and more frequent events in Iowa
column13: the first four states to vote in the nomination contest.\nWhether Rubio can effectively build up his campaign infrastructure in those states may determine whether he can turn his natural political talents and easy appeal with GOP voters into primary victories.\n\"Everywhere I go I hear folks talking about him
column15: a Republican National Committeeman from South Carolina. \"So it's the right time to come into the state
column16: set up shop and set up more time here.\"\nWhile Rubio's advisers say they're simply executing the next phase in a carefully crafted campaign blueprint
column17: there's no doubt the team's early penny-pinching was driven in part by necessity. The senator's fundraising has been underwhelming and his money totals trailed several rivals through summer and fall
column18: including a lackluster $6 million haul in third financial reporting period of the year.\nBut buoyed by strong performances in the last two GOP debates
column19: Rubio has been attracting more high-dollar donors
column20: including billionaire investor Paul Singer and New York hedge fund manager Cliff Asness.\nWith more cash in the pipeline
column21: Rubio is expected to spend more money on travel to early voting states and on larger events aimed at putting him in front of as many voters as possible. Rubio communications director Alex Conant pointed to a 450-person event in New Hampshire last week and a similar sized event in Davenport
column22: Iowa
column23: on Wednesday as examples of the type of settings the candidate will appear at more regularly.\nRubio's more robust travel plans are welcome news to some Republicans in early voting states who have griped for months that the senator wasn't spending enough time on the ground meeting with donors and wooing important backers.
